chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Electoral College reform should aim to keep states central to election administration while making the winner track the national will closely enough that outcomes feel legitimate across regions. A workable middle path is to keep the College but require states to allocate electors proportionally using a uniform ranked-choice ballot, with a single, nationwide recount and audit protocol that triggers automatically in very close elections. That would reduce winner-take-all distortions and swing-state dominance while preserving federalism, improving transparency, and giving voters in every state a real stake in the result.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Reform should preserve federalism and state administration while making outcomes track voter intent more closely and reducing winner-take-all distortions that overemphasize a few swing states. A practical compromise is to keep the Electoral College but allocate electors proportionally (or by district with a statewide component) and bind electors to the certified results, with clear national rules for ballot access, counting, and automatic recount/audit triggers. Pairing these changes with secure, reliable absentee voting for service members and uniform transparency standards can strengthen legitimacy without sidelining smaller states.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Reform should keep states meaningfully involved while making outcomes track voter intent more closely and reducing the sense that only a few swing areas matter. A workable bridge is to keep the Electoral College but require proportional (or district-based) allocation of electors in every state, paired with uniform national standards for ballot access, absentee and military/overseas voting, recount triggers, and transparent audits. Adding ranked-choice voting for president can reduce “spoiler” fears and encourage broader coalition campaigns, improving legitimacy without erasing smaller-state and rural voices.
